column4: hey all, I think I find a bug in ubuntu dapper : I try in /usr/src do this : tar -xvf <TAB> <TAB>. the first <TAB> complete line with this : root@concord:/usr/src# tar -xvf linux-source-2.6.15.tar, but second <TAB> not show nothing and congeals the terminal, but in anoteher temirnal i was running top and I see that first terminal where I set two times <TAB> using 99% of cpu. and machine was reaaly very slowest. That is a bug ?
after 35 seconds second <TAB> show root@concord:/usr/src# tar -xvf linux-source-2.6.15.tar  linux-source-2.6.15/
it's bash completion trying to figure out what further tar options might be reasonable, extracting the tar.gz in the process
this ocurred only with user jpsuser. User jpsuser is one user with root userid and gid : root@concord:~# cat /etc/passwd | grep -i jpsuser
i can reproduce the behaviour with any user and any (large) tar.gz file.
don't use tab when inappropriate, or disable bash_completion, or modify bash_completion to not work with tar.
but with root user this not ocurred, so I would like know how root user can do two times TAB without problems and copy this config to anothers users.. understand ?
which config files are run depends on how the shell is started, and what files are present in a user's home directory
diference between jp user and root is that in jp user I do sudo -i to be root. and using root user I'm don't have problem!
so I would like works in normal user as in root..

err, i don't see enough of a problem to bother with figuring out exactly what causes the difference in behaviour now. i'm just saying bash completion is the cause, and how to fix it is up to a bunch of man pages and config files
but why this problem don't have with root user ?
because a shell behaves differently when called differently and with different user directories.
what config I need do to have equal config in normal user as in root user ?
beouse this is totally insecure, becouse in normal user can use 100% of cpu using only two TABs!!
eh, any user can use 100% cpu time if it's available. try: dd if=/dev/urandom of=/dev/null
.. and at this point you would press ctrl-c or kill the process. problem solved.
